I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  2007  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) includes a regional TA to produce a development framework 
for sustainable urban transport.1 The developing member countries (DMCs) are seeking a new, 
strategic paradigm for sustainable transport systems in their urban areas. This TA responds to 
both  the  DMCs’  demands  and  the  current  and  future  operational  needs  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Rapid urbanization, rising incomes, and an explosive increase in the use and number of 
vehicles have worsened traffic congestion in DMC urban areas. As traffic increases, so do the 
consumption of oil-based fuels and the generation of greenhouse gases (GHGs). Among the 
results are more pollution, environmental degradation, and a declining quality of life in the cities. 
Unfortunately, ways to address these problems, or to stabilize urban sprawl, or curb the growth 
of private vehicle fleets, appear to be out of reach at the moment. 
 
3.  Weighed down by inefficient allocation of road space, inadequate traffic management, 
institutional weaknesses, and insufficient financial resources, the transport systems in most 
cities fail to cope with these tremendous challenges. The development of urban transport has 
been made more difficult by minimal efforts to integrate transport planning with land-use, and a 
lack of attention to the enabling environment.2 
 
4.  The urban poor suffer most from limited access to affordable transport services, ill health 
due to pollution, and poor road safety. Current urban transport systems rarely plan for the 
specific needs of vulnerable groups, and are thereby ineffective in reducing poverty. 
 
5.  Important constraints on sustainable urban transport systems in the cities—as well as  
elements required for success—have been identified through a variety of related ADB activities, 
including an ongoing regional TA for sustainable urban transport.3 They showed that one of the 
biggest mistakes in urban transport is the tendency of governments to design their way out of 
problems through isolated, large-scale capital projects. Experience has demonstrated that this is 
not sustainable and, therefore, a poor approach. 
 
6.  Faced with gridlock and a deteriorating quality of life, governments often turn to instant 
solutions that are doomed to fail. Transport strategies, in those cities that have developed them, 
are often merely lists of priority projects. They contain no strategic vision, coherent policies, or

2   
credible  programming—all  of  which  are  fundamental  requirements  for  sustainable  urban 
transport.  This  brand  of  transport  planning  focuses  on  individual  complexities  rather  than 
examining the overall problem, and devising an overall strategy.  The strategic void is filled 
instead with repeated attempts to improve on what already exists, even when this approach is 
ineffective and new problems call for adaptation and fresh tactics.  
 
7.  While much is already known about how to develop sustainable transport, little has been 
achieved. At the root of urban transport problems is an inability to base strategies not only on 
what is needed, but also on what can be readily accomplished and communicated effectively to 
stakeholders.4 An uncomfortable gap exists between planning and practice. Ambitious wish lists 
do not factor in what the public sector can afford, with the result that much is planned but little 
gets done. Planning has a narrow, technical focus, proceeds without strategic deliberation, and 
produces forecasts that are not “fit-for-purpose.” 
 
8.  What is needed now is an integrated vision that combines various strands of transport 
concerns in a program of activities. Therefore, it is urgent to set a new paradigm based on best 
practices. The paradigm should consist of (i) a long-term vision for sector management, without 
which little can happen; (ii) coherent transport policies that define what must be done; and (iii) 
financing that depends on policy, and that constrains policy as well. This new paradigm should 
harness sufficient resources to confront the scale of these problems. The vision should present 
strategic directions for sustainable transport. A strategic framework should address how to 
deliver that vision. 
 
9.  The regional TA on sustainable urban transport5 confirmed that efforts to cobble together 
transport policies, planning, and programming must be guided, informed, and improved by this 
kind of clear, long-term vision and strategy. The challenges cities face are issues of regional 
and global importance, and the TA noted that the DMCs have made strong demands for a 
development  framework  at  the  strategic  and  regional  levels.  Consultations  with  operations 
departments  in  ADB  also  supported  the  need  for  a  strategic  regional-level  framework  for 
sustainable transport. 
 
10.  Existing work indicated the following requirements: (i) the city government’s substantial 
powers to raise revenues; (ii) the central government’s enforcement of accountability of city 
governments; (iii) planning based on affordability, not on an automatic or unrealistic assumption 
that financing will follow; (iv) planning to produce credible forecasts of demand, revenues, and 
costs; and (v) the reasonable allocation of project risks between the private and public sectors, 
and the willingness of the private sector to finance projects. 
 
11.  The proposed TA will (i) provide a vision with directions for sustainable urban transport, 
and (ii) develop a strategic regional level framework for sustainable urban transport. The TA will

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact of the TA is to promote sustainable development through sustainable urban 
transport systems in the region. The outcome of the TA will be to improve the way cities address 
and provide for the increasing demand for travel, by utilizing long-term visions and packaged 
programs  of  sustainable  transport  systems  that  can  move  people,  goods,  and  services 
efficiently.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will provide these key elements: (i) a strategic vision, with clear-cut directions for 
sustainable urban transport; (ii) a strategic regional development framework for sustainable 
urban transport; and (iii) a regional action plan for clean and efficient energy use in transport. 
The long-term strategic vision will be a basis for credible and clear development targets, provide 
integrated transport solutions, encourage and promote social inclusion, and mitigate negative 
externalities. The strategic development framework will help DMCs in developing effective and 
realistic transport solutions to meet the growing demand for travel. The framework will also 
mitigate the negative externalities of pollution, accidents, and climate change, while ensuring 
equitable access and mobility for all. Future activities will be realigned based on the paradigm to 
be developed under the TA.  
 
14.  The  strategic  regional  development  framework  will  have  three  dimensions:  policy, 
programming, and financing. Coherent policies, derived from a holistic vision of sustainable 
transport, will be constructed on sound analysis and clear principles that complement each 
other and lead to sustainable economic growth, environmental sustainability, and inclusive 
social development. 
 
15.  Issues to be addressed in the framework’s policy agenda will include (i) reducing the 
need for travel, (ii) shifting mode choice towards nonmotorized transport (NMT) and public 
transport, (iii) increasing energy efficiency and combating climate change, (iv) reducing air 
pollution, and (v) reducing poverty. Policy interventions will involve (i) improving NMT and bus 
services, (ii) segregating public transport, (iii) restraining private vehicle use, (iv) managing the 
road network, (v) setting the prices and regulations for public transport, (vi) charging for road 
use,  (vii)  securing  sector  funding,  (viii)  developing  the  road  network,  (ix)  planning  for  city 
expansion, and (x) promoting efficient vehicles and fuels. 
 
16.  Among the social elements of the policy agenda will be  (i) the travel needs of the poor 
or the disadvantaged and their major transport modes—walking, paratransit, and bus services, 
(ii) the role of transport policy in poverty reduction, (iii) managing the road network in favor of the

poor, (iv) rethinking megaprojects, (v) the participation of the urban poor in urban transport, and  
(vi) implementation.7 All the issues on the policy agenda need to fall within the scope of the 
same policy tools. 
 
17.  The  framework  will  address  these  broadly  identified  financing  areas  in  which 
governments could intervene to bring about desired policy outcomes: (i) context and approach; 
(ii) funding, financing, and affordability; (iii) private sector development, especially the role of 
private sector, enabling environment, and new modes; and (iv) innovative financing.  
 
18.  An action plan will be developed for GHG reduction on a regional level. It will be 
designed to (i) improve access to goods and services through an integrated urban plan, (ii) 
reduce  the  fuel  consumed  per  passenger-kilometer  or  freight-kilometer,  (iii)  establish  and 
implement fuel efficiency standards for new vehicles, (iv) increase the use of GHG-friendly 
biofuels for road transport, and (v) improve the fuel efficiency of vehicles. 
 
19.  Building on past and current activities, the TA will enhance ADB’s ability to engage in 
policy dialogue with DMCs, and deliver lending and TA projects in key areas of its operations. It 
will include reviews of successful regional and global experiences, and suggestions on possible 
future directions. The strategic framework will be finalized through extensive consultations within 
ADB  and  externally  with  governments,  stakeholders,  and  donors.  The  TA  findings  will  be 
disseminated  widely  through  various  means,  including  publication,  country  consultation 
workshops, and seminars. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 and will be financed by a grant from ADB’s TA 
funding program. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA.  The  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) will be responsible for the overall and day-to-day monitoring 
of TA activities, including supervising and coordinating the consultants’ work. The TA will involve 
ADB-wide collaboration with the transport community of practice, regional departments, and 
their transport and communications divisions. A technical group, which will be composed of a 
team leader from RSDD and staff selected from relevant departments within ADB, will supervise 
the TA work and provide technical guidance through informal discussions.8  
 
22.  The  TA  will  require  12  person-months  of  services  from  individual  international 
consultants.  Appendix  3  presents  an  outline  of  the  terms  of  reference.  The  international 
consultants will provide expertise in (i) urban transport policy and planning, (ii) urban transport, 
(iii)  transport  energy  efficiency,  and  (iv)  urban  transport  poverty.  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
                                                 
7  Social inclusion is defined as the process of promoting equitable access to the economic and social benefits of 
development. It requires individuals or groups to participate fully in the society in which they live.

consultants will submit the following reports to ADB: (i) inception report, 2 weeks after the start

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
A Development Framework for Sustainable Urban Transport, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require about 12 person-months of services from 
individual international consultants. Under the guidance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
TA team, the consultants will build on the findings of existing work and produce a strategic 
development framework for sustainable transport at the regional level. The consultants will 
provide (i) a strategic vision, with clear-cut directions for sustainable urban transport; (ii) a 
strategic development framework; and (iii) a regional action plan for clean and efficient energy 
use in transport. 
 
2.  The consultants will ensure that TA outputs will enhance ADB’s ability to engage in 
policy dialogue with the selected developing member countries (DMCs) and deliver lending and 
TAs in some key areas of its operations. The consultants will also review successful regional 
and global experiences, while suggesting possible future directions. Under the guidance of the 
ADB TA team, the consultants will organize extensive consultation workshops and seminars, 
inviting national and municipal governments, stakeholders, and development partners. 
 
B.  Consultants 
 
1.  Urban Transport Policy and Planner (5 person-months) 
 
3.  The  transport  specialist  role  is  to  guide  the  work  and  incorporate  the  themes  of 
sustainable economic growth, environmental improvement, and inclusive social development. 
Through the development of a strategic framework, policies, programs, and financing options for 
successful and sustainable urban transport solutions will be defined. Strategic solutions will be 
based  on  credible  and  clear  development  visions,  provide  integrated  transport  solutions, 
encourage and promote social inclusion, and mitigate negative externalities.  
 
4.  The strategic framework will have three dimensions: policy, programming, and financing. 
It will suggest types and modes of transport infrastructure, transport systems, and implementing 
arrangements that meet the refined sustainability criteria. The work will be relevant so that the 
subsequent phase will identify readily sustainable transport solutions for site- or location-specific 
interventions.  The  framework  will  highlight  issues  and  mitigating  measures,  and  define 
strategies to meet the demands of the urban transport sector. 
 
5.  The key tasks will include but not be limited to the following areas: 
 
(i)  Review existing approaches for development of city-level strategies and master 
plans and identify their weaknesses; 
(ii)  Outline the key issues and constraints facing the transport sector in urban areas. 
(iii)  Define  potential  measures  to  address  these  identified  issues,  including  their 
relevance for sustainable urban transport; 
(iv)  Provide a clear vision for sustainable urban transport, which will provide the basis 
of a transport policy, planning and programming; 
(v)  Highlight the interrelationship of project and program interventions over time, and 
between transport modes, as the basis of a strategic vision for transport; 
(vi)  Explore the need for flexibility within the changing environment of the transport 
sector and, in collaboration with the transport policy specialist, propose measures 
to incorporate necessary mechanisms in policy changes and programming;

(viii)  Propose specific areas of actions that will address (a) the need for travel, (b) 
mode integration of travel, (c) the externalities of transport, and (d) travel and

(ix)  Policy agenda in the framework should include these issues: (a) reducing the 
need for travel, (b) shifting mode choice towards nonmotorized transport (NMT) 
and  public  transport,  (c)  increasing  energy  efficiency  and  combating  climate 
change, (d) reducing air pollution, and (e) poverty;  
(x)  Specific policy interventions in the policy agenda should involve (a) improving

(xiii)  Develop best practice examples for sustainable urban transport; and 
(xiv)  Suggest specifications for a risk management system to identify key risks facing

    2.  Urban Transport Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
6.  With the prime objective of developing policy requirements, institutional capacity, and 
suitable financial structure for sustainable and integrated transport solutions, the transport policy 
specialist  will  develop  a  strategic  vision,  structured  policy,  and  program  development  for 
sustainable urban transport. Particular attention is required to demonstrate the benefits strategic 
policies have in delivering sustainable urban transport visions to promote sustainable economic 
growth, environmental sustainability, and inclusive social development. Policy and program 
development requirements must promote holistic and integrated urban transport infrastructure 
and services to ensure efficient and effective operations through well-reasoned and financed 
programming solutions. Policy and planning requirements will be provided to the urban transport 
specialist for inclusion in the strategic framework. 
 
7.  Strategic policies, derived from a holistic vision of sustainable urban transport, will be 
developed that can be adapted to city transport infrastructure and systems. The new policy 
agenda will also integrate the social elements, including (i) the travel needs of the poor or 
disadvantaged and their major transport modes (walking, paratransit, and bus services), (ii) the 
role of transport policy in poverty reduction, and (iii) managing the road network in favor of the 
poor. All the issues on the policy agenda will fall within the scope of the same policy vision and 
tools. 
 
8.  The key tasks will include but not be limited to the following areas: 
 
(i)  Assess  current  transport  policy  and  programming  development  practices, 
including analysis of their success or failures;

4.  Urban Transport Poverty Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
11.  Transport systems must provide for inclusive social development. This consultant will be 
a poverty expert  and be responsible for inclusion of pro-poor and inclusive transport solutions 
within the strategic framework. 
 
12.  The key tasks include but are not limited to the following areas: 
 
(i)  Identify  and  analyze  the  different categories of  urban  poor  and  their  needs. 
Assess the requirements of the travel disadvantaged, identifying which parts of 
society are included in this category and what their travel needs are; 
(ii)  Explore  how  transport  policy,  through  the  strategic  framework,  can  de-
marginalize  the  disadvantaged  in  terms  of  access,  affordability,  economic 
participation, safety, and pollution; 
(iii)  Pay particular attention to the role of NMT and its position within the strategic 
framework and integrated project development;  
(iv)  Assist the transport specialists in integrating social-inclusion elements into the 
new vision, policy, and strategic framework. These should include attention to (a) 
the travel needs of the poor or disadvantaged; (b) the role of transport policy in 
poverty reduction; (c) NMT, including walking, and bus and paratransit services; 
and (d) the management of  the road network in favor of the poor; 
(v)  Suggest how stakeholder engagement and participation in the strategy, strategic 
framework and subsequent project development should be achieved. 
(vi)  Design specific components for transport programs targeting the urban poor, 
such as subsidized travel and innovative fare structures—off-peak and student 
discounts, for example;  
(vii)  Assess the impact of pollution on the poor and propose mitigating measures; 
(viii)  Identify and integrate key social inclusion and environmental concerns into the 
vision and strategic framework to ensure that development benefits accrue to the 
poor; 
(ix)  Present overall strategies to (a) reduce shocks, such as traffic accidents, that can 
create transient poverty; (b) reduce illness and/or death by reducing accidents 
and air pollution; (c) provide access to educational, health, and employment 
facilities; (d) mitigate the lengthening and costly journey to work; and (e) maintain 
family  ties  and  social  networks.  Identify  additional  issues  for  the  travel-
disadvantaged concerning cultural attitudes, accessibility and security; 
(x)  In  collaboration  with  the  transport  specialists,  develop  an  NMT  strategy  for 
inclusion in the strategic framework. There is a major imbalance between the 
significance of NMT and the attention given to these modes in infrastructure 
planning, design, and management;

(xi)  Assist the transport policy specialist in addressing accessibility, environmental 
nuisance, and employment or enterprise issues for the travel-disadvantaged, as 
well as employment in the informal public transport sector; and 
(xii)  Define urban challenges and the role of transport in urban constraints, especially 
for the urban poor. 
 
C.  Reporting 
 
13.  The TA is expected to start in January 2008 and be completed by August 2008. The 
consultants will submit the following reports to ADB: (i) inception report, 2 weeks after the start 
of services; (ii) interim report, 10 weeks after commencement; (iii) draft final report, 14 weeks 
after the start of services; and (iv) final report, 3 weeks after receiving all comments.
